trans-unit.source: High availability features of Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: High availability features of Linux-based HDInsight (Hadoop) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how Linux-based HDInsight clusters improve reliability and availability by using an additional head node.
trans-unit.target: Learn how Linux-based HDInsight clusters improve reliability and availability by using an additional head node.

trans-unit.source: You will learn how this impacts Hadoop services such as Ambari and Hive, as well as how to individually connect to each head node using SSH.
trans-unit.target: You will learn how this impacts Hadoop services such as Ambari and Hive, as well as how to individually connect to each head node using SSH.

trans-unit.source: Availability and reliability of Hadoop clusters in HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Availability and reliability of Hadoop clusters in HDInsight

trans-unit.source: A second head node is used by Linux-based Hadoop clusters deployed by Azure HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: A second head node is used by Linux-based Hadoop clusters deployed by Azure HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: This increases the availability and reliability of Hadoop services and jobs running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This increases the availability and reliability of Hadoop services and jobs running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The steps used in this document are specific to Linux-based HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The steps used in this document are specific to Linux-based HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a Windows-based cluster, see [Availability and reliability of Windows-based Hadoop clusters in HDInsight](hdinsight-high-availability.md) for Windows-specific information.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a Windows-based cluster, see [Availability and reliability of Windows-based Hadoop clusters in HDInsight](hdinsight-high-availability.md) for Windows-specific information.

trans-unit.source: Understanding the head nodes
trans-unit.target: Understanding the head nodes

trans-unit.source: Some implementations of Hadoop have a single head node that hosts services and components that manage the failure of data (worker) nodes smoothly.
trans-unit.target: Some implementations of Hadoop have a single head node that hosts services and components that manage the failure of data (worker) nodes smoothly.

trans-unit.source: But any outages of master services running on the head node would cause the cluster to cease to work.
trans-unit.target: But any outages of master services running on the head node would cause the cluster to cease to work.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight clusters provide a secondary head node, which allows master services and components to continue to run on on the secondary node in the event of a failure on the primary.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight clusters provide a secondary head node, which allows master services and components to continue to run on on the secondary node in the event of a failure on the primary.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Both head nodes are active and running within the cluster simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Both head nodes are active and running within the cluster simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: Some services, such as HDFS or YARN, are only 'active' on one head node at any given time (and ‘standby’ on the other head node).
trans-unit.target: Some services, such as HDFS or YARN, are only 'active' on one head node at any given time (and ‘standby’ on the other head node).

trans-unit.source: Other services such as HiveServer2 or Hive MetaStore are active on both head nodes at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Other services such as HiveServer2 or Hive MetaStore are active on both head nodes at the same time.

trans-unit.source: [ZooKeeper](http://zookeeper.apache.org/ ) nodes (ZKs) are used for leader election of master services on head nodes, and to insure that services, data (worker) nodes and gateways know which head node a master service is active on.
trans-unit.target: [ZooKeeper](http://zookeeper.apache.org/ ) nodes (ZKs) are used for leader election of master services on head nodes, and to insure that services, data (worker) nodes and gateways know which head node a master service is active on.

trans-unit.source: Accessing the head nodes
trans-unit.target: Accessing the head nodes

trans-unit.source: In general, all access to the cluster through the public gateways (Ambari web and REST APIs,) is not effected by having multiple head nodes.
trans-unit.target: In general, all access to the cluster through the public gateways (Ambari web and REST APIs,) is not effected by having multiple head nodes.

trans-unit.source: The request is routed to the active head node and serviced as appropriate.
trans-unit.target: The request is routed to the active head node and serviced as appropriate.

trans-unit.source: When accessing the cluster using SSH, connecting through port 22 (the default for SSH,) will connect to head node 0; connecting through port 23 will connect to head node 1.
trans-unit.target: When accessing the cluster using SSH, connecting through port 22 (the default for SSH,) will connect to head node 0; connecting through port 23 will connect to head node 1.

trans-unit.source: Internal fully qualified domain names (FQDN)
trans-unit.target: Internal fully qualified domain names (FQDN)

trans-unit.source: Nodes in an HDInsight cluster have an internal IP address and FQDN that can only be accessed from the cluster (such as an SSH session to the head node or a job running on the cluster.) When accessing services on the cluster using the internal FQDN or IP address, you should use Ambari to verify the IP or FQDN to use when accessing the service.
trans-unit.target: Nodes in an HDInsight cluster have an internal IP address and FQDN that can only be accessed from the cluster (such as an SSH session to the head node or a job running on the cluster.) When accessing services on the cluster using the internal FQDN or IP address, you should use Ambari to verify the IP or FQDN to use when accessing the service.

trans-unit.source: For example, the Oozie service can only run on one head node, and using the `oozie` command from an SSH session requires the URL to the service.
trans-unit.target: For example, the Oozie service can only run on one head node, and using the `oozie` command from an SSH session requires the URL to the service.

trans-unit.source: This can be retrieved from Ambari by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: This can be retrieved from Ambari by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: This will return a value similar to the following, which contains the internal URL to use with the `oozie` command:
trans-unit.target: This will return a value similar to the following, which contains the internal URL to use with the `oozie` command:

trans-unit.source: How to check on a service status
trans-unit.target: How to check on a service status

trans-unit.source: Either the Ambari Web UI or the Ambari REST API can be used to check the status of services that run on the head node.
trans-unit.target: Either the Ambari Web UI or the Ambari REST API can be used to check the status of services that run on the head node.

trans-unit.source: Ambari REST API
trans-unit.target: Ambari REST API

trans-unit.source: You can use the following command to check the state of a service through the Ambari REST API:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following command to check the state of a service through the Ambari REST API:

trans-unit.source: Replace **PASSWORD** with the HTTP user (admin,) account password
trans-unit.target: Replace **PASSWORD** with the HTTP user (admin,) account password

trans-unit.source: Replace **CLUSTERNAME** with the name of the cluster
trans-unit.target: Replace **CLUSTERNAME** with the name of the cluster

trans-unit.source: Replace **SERVICENAME** with the name of the service to check the status of
trans-unit.target: Replace **SERVICENAME** with the name of the service to check the status of

trans-unit.source: For example, to check the status of the **HDFS** service on a cluster named **mycluster**, with a password of **password**, you would use the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, to check the status of the **HDFS** service on a cluster named **mycluster**, with a password of **password**, you would use the following:

trans-unit.source: The response will be similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The response will be similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: The URL tells us that the service is currently running on **head node 0**.
trans-unit.target: The URL tells us that the service is currently running on **head node 0**.

trans-unit.source: The state tells us that the service is currently running, or **STARTED**.
trans-unit.target: The state tells us that the service is currently running, or **STARTED**.

trans-unit.source: If you do not know what services are installed on the cluster, you can use the following to retrieve a list:
trans-unit.target: If you do not know what services are installed on the cluster, you can use the following to retrieve a list:

trans-unit.source: Service components
trans-unit.target: Service components

trans-unit.source: Services may contain components that you wish to check the status of individually.
trans-unit.target: Services may contain components that you wish to check the status of individually.

trans-unit.source: For example, HDFS contains the NameNode component.
trans-unit.target: For example, HDFS contains the NameNode component.

trans-unit.source: To view information on a component, the command would be:
trans-unit.target: To view information on a component, the command would be:

trans-unit.source: If you do not know what components are provided by a service, you can use the following to retrieve a list:
trans-unit.target: If you do not know what components are provided by a service, you can use the following to retrieve a list:

trans-unit.source: Ambari Web UI
trans-unit.target: Ambari Web UI

trans-unit.source: The Ambari Web UI is viewable at https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: The Ambari Web UI is viewable at https://CLUSTERNAME.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: Replace **CLUSTERNAME** with the name of your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Replace **CLUSTERNAME** with the name of your cluster.

trans-unit.source: If prompted, enter the HTTP user credentials for your cluster.
trans-unit.target: If prompted, enter the HTTP user credentials for your cluster.

trans-unit.source: The default HTTP user name is **admin** and the password is the password you entered when creating the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The default HTTP user name is **admin** and the password is the password you entered when creating the cluster.

trans-unit.source: When you arrive on the Ambari page, the installed services will be listed on the left of the page.
trans-unit.target: When you arrive on the Ambari page, the installed services will be listed on the left of the page.

trans-unit.source: ![Installed services](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/services.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Installed services](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/services.png)

trans-unit.source: There are a series of icons that may appear next to a service to indicate status.
trans-unit.target: There are a series of icons that may appear next to a service to indicate status.

trans-unit.source: Any alerts related to a service can be viewed using the **Alerts** link at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Any alerts related to a service can be viewed using the **Alerts** link at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: You can select each service to view more information on it.
trans-unit.target: You can select each service to view more information on it.

trans-unit.source: While the service page provides information on the status and configuration of each service, it does not provide information on which head node the service is running on.
trans-unit.target: While the service page provides information on the status and configuration of each service, it does not provide information on which head node the service is running on.

trans-unit.source: To view this information, use the **Hosts** link at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: To view this information, use the **Hosts** link at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: This will display hosts within the cluster, including the head nodes.
trans-unit.target: This will display hosts within the cluster, including the head nodes.

trans-unit.source: ![hosts list](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/hosts.png)
trans-unit.target: ![hosts list](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/hosts.png)

trans-unit.source: Selecting the link for one of the head nodes will display the services and components running on that node.
trans-unit.target: Selecting the link for one of the head nodes will display the services and components running on that node.

trans-unit.source: ![Component status](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/nodeservices.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Component status](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/nodeservices.png)

trans-unit.source: How to access log files on the secondary head node
trans-unit.target: How to access log files on the secondary head node

trans-unit.source: SSH
trans-unit.target: SSH

trans-unit.source: While connected to a head node through SSH, log files can be found under **/var/log**.
trans-unit.target: While connected to a head node through SSH, log files can be found under **/var/log**.

trans-unit.source: For example, **/var/log/hadoop-yarn/yarn** contain logs for YARN.
trans-unit.target: For example, **/var/log/hadoop-yarn/yarn** contain logs for YARN.

trans-unit.source: Each head node can have unique log entries, so you should check the logs on both.
trans-unit.target: Each head node can have unique log entries, so you should check the logs on both.

trans-unit.source: Ambari
trans-unit.target: Ambari

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Accessing log files through Ambari requires an SSH tunnel, as the web sites for the individual services are not exposed publicly on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Accessing log files through Ambari requires an SSH tunnel, as the web sites for the individual services are not exposed publicly on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: For information on using an SSH tunnel, see [Use SSH Tunneling to access Ambari web UI, ResourceManager, JobHistory, NameNode, Oozie, and other web UI's](hdinsight-linux-ambari-ssh-tunnel.md).
trans-unit.target: For information on using an SSH tunnel, see [Use SSH Tunneling to access Ambari web UI, ResourceManager, JobHistory, NameNode, Oozie, and other web UI's](hdinsight-linux-ambari-ssh-tunnel.md).

trans-unit.source: From the Ambari Web UI, select the service you wish to view logs for (for example, YARN,) and then use **Quick Links** to select which head node to view the logs for.
trans-unit.target: From the Ambari Web UI, select the service you wish to view logs for (for example, YARN,) and then use **Quick Links** to select which head node to view the logs for.

trans-unit.source: ![Using quick links to view logs](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/viewlogs.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Using quick links to view logs](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/viewlogs.png)

trans-unit.source: How to configure the size of the head node
trans-unit.target: How to configure the size of the head node

trans-unit.source: The size of the head node can only be selected during cluster creation.
trans-unit.target: The size of the head node can only be selected during cluster creation.

trans-unit.source: You can find a list of the different VM sizes available for HDInsight, including the core, memory, and local storage for each, on the [HDInsight pricing page](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/hdinsight/).
trans-unit.target: You can find a list of the different VM sizes available for HDInsight, including the core, memory, and local storage for each, on the [HDInsight pricing page](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/hdinsight/).

trans-unit.source: When creating a new cluster, you can specify the size of the nodes.
trans-unit.target: When creating a new cluster, you can specify the size of the nodes.

trans-unit.source: The following provide information on how to specify the size using the [Azure Portal][preview-portal], [Azure PowerShell][azure-powershell], and the [Azure CLI][azure-cli]:
trans-unit.target: The following provide information on how to specify the size using the [Azure Portal][preview-portal], [Azure PowerShell][azure-powershell], and the [Azure CLI][azure-cli]:

trans-unit.source: **Azure Portal**: When creating a new cluster, you are given the option of setting the size (pricing tier,) of both the head and data (worker) nodes for the cluster:
trans-unit.target: **Azure Portal**: When creating a new cluster, you are given the option of setting the size (pricing tier,) of both the head and data (worker) nodes for the cluster:

trans-unit.source: ![Image of cluster creation wizard with node size selection](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/headnodesize.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Image of cluster creation wizard with node size selection](./media/hdinsight-high-availability-linux/headnodesize.png)

trans-unit.source: **Azure CLI**: When using the `azure hdinsight cluster create` command, you can set the size of the head node using the `--headNodeSize` parameter.
trans-unit.target: **Azure CLI**: When using the `azure hdinsight cluster create` command, you can set the size of the head node using the `--headNodeSize` parameter.

trans-unit.source: **Azure PowerShell**: When using the `New-AzureRmHDInsightCluster` cmdlet, you can set the size of the head node using the `-HeadNodeVMSize` parameter.
trans-unit.target: **Azure PowerShell**: When using the `New-AzureRmHDInsightCluster` cmdlet, you can set the size of the head node using the `-HeadNodeVMSize` parameter.

trans-unit.target: In this document you have learned how Azure HDInsight provides high availability for Hadoop.
